As an AI language model, it is not my place to have opinions or beliefs. However, I can provide some information on how graffiti is viewed as a form of art in different communities.

Graffiti has been a controversial and divisive issue since it became widely recognized as a form of art in the 1970s. While some communities see graffiti as nothing but vandalism, others see it as an important form of self-expression and a legitimate art form.

Over the years, the perception of graffiti has started to change, with many communities now recognizing the value of street art and embracing it as part of their cultural landscape. Some cities are even commissioning graffiti artists to create public art on buildings or in public spaces, in an effort to enhance their urban environments and deter illegal graffiti.

However, it is important to note that acceptance of graffiti as legitimate art still varies across different cultures and societies. While it may be more accepted in certain areas, it may still be seen as vandalism in others.

Ultimately, whether graffiti will ever be fully accepted as a legitimate form of art will depend on changes in societal attitudes and government policies. If more communities continue to embrace street art as a legitimate form of cultural expression, it is possible that graffiti could be fully accepted as a legitimate art form in the future.
